comments.text:
Answer, and thank you for the post Jayztwocents (youtubers):

To be clear:

AMD Radeon RX 9000 series : These GPUs are expected to use PCIe 5.0 x16, with a raw bi-directional bandwidth of 128 GB/s (64 GB/s per direction). With 2:1 compression, the effective bi-directional bandwidth could reach 256 GB/s.

Nvidia GeForce RTX 5000 series (non-Ada, released in 2025): These GPUs  use PCIe 5.0 x16, with the same bandwidth characteristics as above.

PS5's GPU has a theoretical maximum bandwidth of 448 GB/s to the GDDR6 memory.


This is the peak transfer rate that the memory can achieve. (though this is not directly comparable to PCIe bandwidth, as it's a separate internal interconnect.) The GPU and CPU share the same pool of GDDR6 memory, eliminating the need to copy data between separate system RAM and VRAM (which happens on a PC). 


Why is this important? This is the barrier AMD and Nvidia have to overcome in PCI6 or something similar. Simply increasing PCIe bandwidth (with PCIe 6.0, 7.0, etc.) won't completely solve the problem if data still needs to be copied between separate memory pools.

While PCIe 5.0 represents a significant generational leap in interface bandwidth, it doesn't address the fundamental advantage of the PS5's unified memory architecture and dedicated I/O hardware. The core challenge remains minimizing data movement and latency between storage, CPU, and GPU.


PCIe 5.0 doubles the bandwidth of PCIe 4.0, enabling significantly faster data transfer. A PCIe 5.0 x16 connection (used by GPUs) offers 128 GB/s bi-directional bandwidth (64 GB/s per direction). With a 2:1 compression ratio, the effective bi-directional bandwidth could reach 256 GB/s. A PCIe 5.0 x4 connection (used by NVMe SSDs) provides 16 GB/s per direction. The PS5's custom I/O achieves 5.5 GB/s raw read speeds and 8-9 GB/s (or higher) with compression, thanks to its dedicated hardware. While current consumer GPUs don't have the same dedicated hardware, technologies like DirectStorage are evolving to improve GPU-based decompression. The PS5's internal GPU memory bandwidth (448 GB/s) is a separate metric and not directly comparable to PCIe bandwidth.

 PS5 has a custom I/O complex with dedicated hardware for decompression, allowing it to achieve those impressive compressed speeds. (and this is like 4-5 years old Technology now) Current GPUs from AMD and Nvidia don't fully exploit PCIe 5.0's capabilities, particularly in terms of compressed bandwidth, and this is the issue, the lack of hardware decompression - or a way to bypass the encoding-decoding-cache process. The PS5, with its dedicated hardware, can bypass much of this overhead, achieving higher effective throughput with compressed data, even though its raw PCIe bandwidth (likely 4.0 x4) is lower than a PC's PCIe 5.0 x16.

Once again, PS5's I/O for Hard-drive is up to 9-10 gb/s compressed, is old tech now, in 2025. The APU is almost 450 GB/s (though still holds up) Artificial intelligence could play a crucial role in optimizing I/O performance (this is more expected today).  PCIe 5.0 theoretical potential, 256 GB/s, PS5's GPU memory bandwidth, 448 GB/s. AMD and Nvidia's line drop here, does not provide that compressed bandwidth potential. The fundamental shift is to PCIe 5, but it doesn't reach the level of the APU that is integrated within the Playstation 5.


 Secondly and next, we need to benchmark in 8K as the standard, and next year's standard. It's a logical next step for benchmarking as displays and content that support 8K become more prevalent. Thus, And a true Data I/O benchmark and VRAM storage for "computational storage" and assets storage, is also the real and best complimentary benchmarks. Modern Apps and Games rely heavily on fast access to large datasets and efficient asset streaming. VRAM capacity and speed are becoming increasingly important as datasets grow larger and more complex. Developing standardized tests that specifically evaluate 8K performance, data I/O, and VRAM utilization is crucial for fair and consistent comparisons. 

Lastly, Stability is still one of the top most important measurements for Robustness, AMD and Nvidia cannot abandon that, even though haven't, but if they have ... this is more important than inference time etc. While inference time (the time it takes for a model to process data and produce a result) is an important metric, especially in AI applications, it shouldn't come at the cost of stability. A slightly slower but stable system is often preferable to a faster but unreliable one. As GPUs become more complex and powerful, and as software pushes their limits further, maintaining stability becomes even more challenging. It's crucial that AMD and Nvidia continue to prioritize stability alongside performance advancements. But once again, and, to their credit, both AMD and Nvidia have generally maintained a strong focus on stability in their GPU designs. They invest significant resources in testing, validation, and driver development to ensure their products deliver reliable performance.

comments.text:
Thus, what do people want? (from PCIe 5.0, since Unified Memory system like in PS5's optimized APU or even a smartphone)

Speed: Faster loading times (games, applications, files), faster processing (rendering, encoding, compiling), faster everything.

Smoothness: No stuttering, no lag, consistent performance, especially in demanding applications like games and video editing.

Responsiveness: A system that feels quick and reactive, even under heavy load, with minimal delays.

Efficiency: Getting the most performance out of their hardware investment; maximizing the utilization of the GPU, CPU, and storage.


How This Is Achieved (Technical Enablers):

To deliver these desired outcomes, several key technologies and architectural improvements are crucial. These often involve shifting tasks away from the traditional CPU-centric model and leveraging the GPU's parallel processing power:

DirectStorage (and similar technologies): This is currently the most impactful technology. DirectStorage allows the GPU to bypass the CPU and directly access data from NVMe SSDs. This significantly reduces latency and CPU overhead, leading to faster loading times and smoother gameplay. This is a direct enabler of Speed, Smoothness, and Responsiveness.

GPU-Based Decompression: Offloading data decompression from the CPU to the GPU is critical for maximizing the benefits of DirectStorage and fast SSDs. The GPU's massively parallel architecture is far better suited for this task than the CPU. This directly enables Speed and Efficiency.

Increased VRAM Capacity (this is what everyone or many are buzzing about, this specific area and number) and Efficiency: The GPU's VRAM acts as a high-speed buffer for data the GPU is actively using. Larger VRAM capacities allow for storing more data (higher resolution textures, larger datasets), and more efficient VRAM management reduces the need to fetch data from slower storage. This primarily enables Smoothness and Efficiency, and is also necessary for Speed in many cases.

Computational Storage (Future Potential): This is a longer-term concept where processing tasks are performed directly on the SSD by a dedicated processor on the SSD itself. While not directly involving the GPU, it shares the same principle of moving computation closer to the data to reduce latency and improve efficiency. This could potentially contribute to Speed and Efficiency in the future.



The common thread among these technologies is a shift in responsibilities. The GPU is taking on some specific tasks related to data access and processing that are currently handled by the CPU and traditional filesystem interactions. This shift leverages the GPU's strengths (parallel processing, high-bandwidth memory) and reduces the bottlenecks associated with the traditional CPU-centric data path. This is key to unlocking the full potential of PCIe 5.0 and fast NVMe SSDs.

comments.text:
So, got a video/series request for you guys as it's a conversation we don't hear much and I think it would be good to hear it from you with your recent comments of PC gaming becoming a rich mans hobby.

I would like to hear/see a conversation around native resolutions, upscaling,  performance, and fps for budget buyers.

Personally, I think native resolutions tend to look better (read 1440p native vs 4k upscaled) than the upscaled resolutions. Also, I think having a solid 60 fps in all games besides shooters is more than enough if you're on a budget. Plus, seeing budget builds that rock 1080p/1440p (most popular resolutions according to steam) would be cool to see, especially ones you could using upscaling to hit 4k/60 if it can be proven that upscaling ever manages to look better than a native resolution

comments.text: No one ever talks about how GPUs preform when running emulators. It's always about the 'latest titles'. Obviously those need to be mentioned, but they're not the only game in town. And it will likely always be true that the best video games ever made, were already made; even if those titles were released only a generation ago. It would be nice if reviews didn't pretend that gaming began and ended with whatever crap the self-proclaimed 'triple-A' studios are currently pushing. Emulators have a different relationship with GPUs than do games designed from the ground up to run on PCs. They are often more hardware-hungry than are current PC games; due in-part to software antiquation. For example, I doubt that any emulators out there now know what to do with NVIDIA's "fake frames". If someone is planning a PC build and, in addition to modern computing, plans to do a sizable portion of their gaming via emulation, which hardware should they be looking at? But I do understand that it could be risky to make videos which even elude to modern console emulation being possible. IE: Switch emulation vs Nintendo's in-house law-firm.

comments.text:
Hey @jayztwocents! So, I watched your video and you mentioned something interesting @19:46 about this review where the new AMD cards felt smoother than anything you've noticed before. I'm super sensitive to latency and responsiveness in games, and I don't play anything competitively, just mostly racing games like from Codemasters and EA. I have an AMD RX 6800 Sapphire Pulse I've been playing on for the last couple of years (so I'm very familiar with how games feel on it) and I just installed the new 25.3.1 drivers and I've noticed the same thing. The responsiveness and smoothness have been greatly improved. Almost like they reduced the latency all around or overhead for the drivers because everything I play just feels much better than before. Doesn't matter if it's newer games like Dirt Rally 2.0 or Talos Principle 2, or older games like NFSMW 2005/2012, ETS2/ATS, Grid series, heck even Dolphin feels better. Regardless if it's limited to 60fps or maxes out my Gigabyte M32Q, it all just feels smoother and more responsive.

Could this be something you check into, even with older cards and see if the newer drivers are somehow more efficient?

comments.text:
12:03. It's not that "Black Myth doesnt, like, these cards", it's just NOT Optimized. I get pointing out a game that doesnt work well with AMD, but i suggest pushing developers to FIX these issues, is the approach I'd take (remember Cyberpunk on AMD upon release?). Black Myth should work better with AMD GPUs in the future, and people need to put some pressure on Game Science, the developer, for Better Optimization. 

Cyberpunk, the Nvidia sponsored title was discovered to be using old Radeon code that bricked performance for AMD when it was released. Not sure the contract with Nvidia, but CD Projekt Red took their sweet time fixing performance issues with AMD GPUs. In short, I hope this industry doesnt get comfortable with any large developer bricking competition for whatever reason or compensation that no one's supposed to know about, that'll effect 100s of thousands of gamers all because some corporate heads want to make a few bucks more. We need to mention and push for better optimization across all GPU teams, Red, Green or Blue.

Also just found out they only have 28 stores in the entire U.S,  in very unlikely I'll ever be in a MicroCenter since the closest store is a bit over 100 miles each way, so MicroCenter is useless to me, since I'm not driving that far if I can't pay first or ask for an item to be held for the hour or two it will take just to get there. For me and others not near a MicroCenter store, this launch is no better in any way than the 5070 ti launch. I thought online sellers like Best Buy would have some protection from bots, since it's happened before. I suppose they have no incentive to block scalpers since they get paid either way. comments.text:
Its amazing how quickly the Green vs Red battle begins in these comments.  Just speaking from a last gen perspective, I can say im leaning AMD on this gen.  I'm not looking at their max capabilities to make an opinion because only 5% to 10% will ever see their max capabilities.   The AMD card just seems to be more polished in performance vs the NVidia card.  Too many spikes can actually lead to a bad gaming experience.  A more consistent card with more perceived stability leads to a better gaming experience because its predictable. 

One more thing to note.  1080p is all but dead to me now.  I dont look at 1080p results anymore.  CPU framerate issues are all but extinct.  Now YouTube videos, are all but the last remnants of 1080p to me.  Ive been 1440 dedicated now for about a year and a half, and even watching videos or TV in 1080p just sort of irks me.  Yes, ive become a 1440 snob but also its just a better experience.  4k just doesnt grab my interest yet because its just cumbersome to even really set it up for an enjoyable experience.  I've have the hardware to run 4k, its nice, but not fun to optimize.

Great video Jay, I think you're pretty much spot on in your review.  NVidia really needs to clean up their act.  AMD seams ready to pounce on that major blunder that NVidia always seems to make during their generational so called leap.

comments.text: Standard deviation is the term you need when youre discussing the frame time. You're looking for a low Standard deviation and a low mean. You can compare the standard deviation and mean, using the coefficient of variance. It's the (sd/mean)*100 . In words, divide the standard deviation by the mean and multiply that value by 100. The result is a % which you could use to compare frame rate performance across cards. A low CV % is good. A high CV % is bad.

comments.text:
Dear Jay,

Please do a comparison of the RX 9070 XT vs RTX 5070 Ti with overclocking.

Why?  From Der8auer's OC attempt on the RTX 5070 Ti and Hardware Unboxed's results, the RTX 5070 Ti may have been cheating.  HUB tries to set their GPU vs GPU comparisons by ensuring the cards are set to AMD/Nvidia reference settings.  Given HUB received a $900 premium RTX 5070 Ti officially for the $750 reference card review, i am suspicious that the RTX 5070 Ti did not fully accept the weaker settings.  I know for AMD cards that max clock is max clock, but it seems for Nvidia, the max clock is like a suggestion that is surpassed if power limit permits.

comments.text:
In other news. I've been confused for years on this:
Both Microsoft and Sony have used semi-custom AMD SOC's (using various AMD graphics technologies) for years in the X-Box and Play Station. 
Thus: Why don't (or aren't)  the optimisations that are clearly performed for those use cases able to be implemented in the PC space? 

Game designers must know the AMD silicone intimately by this point and what it takes to get every last bit out of it. yet... While the 5070Ti is poorly priced. it provides equal to slightly better performance using only 45.6B transistors vs the 53.9B transistors (using more power in the process.) Indicating that it is far more efficient and power dense...

Still keen to get a 9070XT to replace my RX9600XT that's having a few ongoing issues, if i can get one in Aus for close to MSRP.

comments.text:
Hope you can follow up with something like picture quality comparison especially talking about upscaling.

Why - I followed your advice back in 2019 and went for 5700XT instead of team green. Overall I am happy with the choice: saved some money, card works well, can run games at 1440p with fair amount of details, it still holds ok even with crazy consuming titles like Last of us and God of war (gave it tough time).
On the flip side (no comparison, haven't seen 3-series Nvidia in real life) AMD Radeon software is just still quite buggy, with some titles it crashes almost weekly (e.g. Apex Legends) and any overcloock does crash the card in many games as well. Also this bug with settings set per game just defaulting, stuff turning itself on has been very annoying to the point where I had to take screenshots of all settings to be able to remake them 1:1 as soon as software does its thing.
And upscaling just makes games look borderline bad.
Finally what drove me insane is sharpness setting - without it on I guess I am not able to run any game at all. Not sure who and why invented it as lower values just makes you see as nearsighted person - who would use that? - while feature on and especially on higher 80-100% values makes games look like they don't have AA on = jagged edges, artifacts, blinking pixels and what not.

Long story short - at this point if I would have to I would actually look for a deal for 4070ti - 4080 and spend more vs going with AMD despite it being cheaper.
Based on the games and online info Nvidia just looks better and software gives a lot more options, advantages especially in FPS games, more stability etc. Add to that the fact that upscaling (I assume) for 4080 is still better or for sure not worse than 9070XTX...in my books that's a big plus.

comments.text:
I really, really wanted to check out AMD again (last time I tried ATI/AMD over 15 years ago was a debacle).  I wanted them to win me over on their GPUs like they have with their CPUs.  Intel had enough serious misteps and the 2xx chips are "meh" so AMD is an easy switch.

It looked like Nvidia was trending the same way, basically stepping on their own d**k through the whole 50xx launch it would be easy to go with a AMD GPU too but the price difference between the 9070 XT and 5070ti isn't significant enough to sway me.  The performance delta, even just basic rastor much less with RT, DLSS, and MFG make the 5070ti the clear winner in my mind.

The 5070ti will last me years and years.  I feel like if I go with the 9070 XT I will be shopping for an upgrade in a year or two.  As much as people want to poop on Nvidia, AMD isn't competing with them in this gen except by exceeding the very entry level of performance of the 5070FE.  For God's sake, they're competing with Intel to be winner of the low end!  And on the low end Iris and Alchemist/Battle Mage are going to eat AMDs lunch.

I really enjoyed the new approach you are taking to reviewing these video cards. Regardless of the state of the market pricing and other issues going on with GPUs on the NVIDIA side I can see how you are taking the advice from GN and integrating your own way. Your channel was always one which consider to be both entertaining and informative. Keep up the work toward the new style and integrating new testing methods.

I am very happy to see AMD hasn't stumbled hard on the performance of the RDNA 4 enabled cards so far. We all kind of needed them to bring a stable and competitive product to market and finally they seem to have done so. I LOVED the 7900XTX and RX 6000 series too. The only think we're missing is a top end competitor but releasing such strong upper mid-tier competition is very welcome and if they really are stable and performant that is extremely promising for the future.

I feel like Radeon had been stumbling since AMD absorbed ATI. Hopefully this is an indication of their future potential and trajectory. Once they re-merge their architectures hopefully they can keep this up and get things rolling higher in the product stack in the hopefully near future.

comments.text: 3Dmark is an artificial benchmark for GPUs, and the results are what they are - cards score higher because they are better on this benchmark, which may or may not emulate their performance in any specific game or other 3d graphical task.  My guess for the seemingly strange result is that Nvidia decided to focus their attention on some aspect of performance that 3dmark doesn't measure, or at least doesn't prioritise in its scoring.

comments.text:
Ok, here is my case for the 9070 vs the XT:

While it's not much cheaper upfront, the much lower power draw leads to a lower electricity bill and that can make a huge difference in many places. Electricity is plain expensive for some people. Averaging 4 hours a day of GPU usage with a price of 29ct per kilowatt hour (that seems to be the average price in Germany), I got to a savings of ~42€ per year when dropping to the non-XT. So after a bit over a year, the price gap will have doubled.

It's also going to heat up much less, in turn producing less fan noise, making it nicer to be around.

Is this going to matter for many? Probably not. But it's not that bad a tradeoff.

comments.text:
It makes me happy to see that the 7900XTX and 9070XT are basically neck n' neck with most the tests. I personally have a 7900XTX with a 7800X3D, and i can easily hit 160FPS in most the games i play, which are at high-ultra settings at 1440p, upscaled to my monitors native 4k resolution. But most the time with my more graphic intensive games, like Cyberpunk without RT, my FPS is pretty inconsistent.
Same thing can be said with Fortnite at 1080p Ultra. My monitor can output 320FPS with its frame boost mode, but my FPS is VERY inconsistent. Dropping down to the 140's at times and consistently bouncing between the 250-320 rapidly. comments.text:
People are focusing on the weak features, and not really the correct areas. And the VRAM focus is very very telling and the I/O or eyes on the I/O are, the focus on, are very telling.

For example: PCIe 5.0 represents a significant generational leap, doubling the bandwidth of PCIe 4.0. This enables much faster data transfer between components like GPUs, SSDs, and other peripherals. A PCIe 5.0 x16 connection (typically used by GPUs) offers a raw bi-directional bandwidth of 128 GB/s (64 GB/s per direction). With a highly efficient compression algorithm achieving a 2:1 ratio, the effective bi-directional bandwidth could reach 256 GB/s. A PCIe 5.0 x4 connection (used by NVMe SSDs) provides 16 GB/s per direction.

The PS5, in contrast, utilizes a custom I/O complex with dedicated hardware decompression, allowing its SSD to achieve 5.5 GB/s raw read speeds and 8-9 GB/s (or higher) with compressed data. While this is based on a likely PCIe 4.0 x4 connection, the dedicated hardware is the key differentiator. Current consumer GPUs from AMD and Nvidia, while benefiting from PCIe 5.0's increased raw bandwidth, don't have that same dedicated hardware decompression that makes the PS5 so special. Remember that 256 GB/s figure we talked about for PCIe 5.0? That's with compression, and it's for moving data between parts of the PC. The PS5, on the other hand, has a whopping 448 GB/s of bandwidth inside its GPU, for accessing its memory. It's a different kind of speed, but it shows how optimized the PS5 is.

Technologies like Direct Storage are improving GPU-based decompression, but they don't yet fully match the PS5's integrated approach. This difference in I/O architecture, specifically the efficient handling of compressed data, is a key advantage of the PS5, even though it's a few years old now. AI could play a significant role in further optimizing I/O performance on PCs in the future.

Thus, the 256 GB/s figure (representing the effective, compressed, bi-directional bandwidth of a PCIe 5.0 x16 connection) highlights the potential bottleneck relative to the PS5's overall I/O performance, but not in the way one might initially think. It's not a bottleneck of PCIe 5.0 itself in isolation, but rather a bottleneck in the overall PC architecture compared to the PS5's highly integrated and optimized design. Data copying overhead, the series of data transfers and processing steps required on a PC,  PS5, by streamlining this process, achieves better effective I/O performance. The number itself (256 GB/s) is high, but the way that number is achieved (and the limitations in achieving it consistently) is where the bottleneck lies.

 With rise of SoCs and APUs, it's possible that Nvidia will need to adapt its strategy, potentially by developing its own high-performance APUs, to remain competitive in the long term. However, it's also important to remember that the discrete GPU market is still very strong. But they will have to address the PCI5.0 bottleneck, but that being said, 256 GB/s is more than ample, for many many things, but to showcase a bottleneck, over a technology that is 5 years older, we need to consider effective throughput, not just theoretical bandwidth. The PS5, despite having lower raw PCIe bandwidth, achieves higher effective I/O performance for game assets due to its optimized design, which means the potential highest benchmarks are faster and better texture streaming, for less pop-in, and a smoother overall gaming experience.

Thus, what do people want? (from PCIe 5.0)

Speed: Faster loading times (games, applications, files), faster processing (rendering, encoding, compiling), faster everything.
Smoothness: No stuttering, no lag, consistent performance, especially in demanding applications like games and video editing.
Responsiveness: A system that feels quick and reactive, even under heavy load, with minimal delays.
Efficiency: Getting the most performance out of their hardware investment; maximizing the utilization of the GPU, CPU, and storage.
How This Is Achieved (Technical Enablers):

To deliver these desired outcomes, several key technologies and architectural improvements are crucial. These often involve shifting tasks away from the traditional CPU-centric model and leveraging the GPU's parallel processing power:

DirectStorage (and similar technologies): This is currently the most impactful technology. DirectStorage allows the GPU to bypass the CPU and directly access data from NVMe SSDs. This significantly reduces latency and CPU overhead, leading to faster loading times and smoother gameplay. This is a direct enabler of Speed, Smoothness, and Responsiveness.

GPU-Based Decompression: Offloading data decompression from the CPU to the GPU is critical for maximizing the benefits of DirectStorage and fast SSDs. The GPU's massively parallel architecture is far better suited for this task than the CPU. This directly enables Speed and Efficiency.

Increased VRAM Capacity and Efficiency: The GPU's VRAM acts as a high-speed buffer for data the GPU is actively using. Larger VRAM capacities allow for storing more data (higher resolution textures, larger datasets), and more efficient VRAM management reduces the need to fetch data from slower storage. This primarily enables Smoothness and Efficiency, and is also necessary for Speed in many cases.

Computational Storage (Future Potential): This is a longer-term concept where processing tasks are performed directly on the SSD by a dedicated processor on the SSD itself. While not directly involving the GPU, it shares the same principle of moving computation closer to the data to reduce latency and improve efficiency. This could potentially contribute to Speed and Efficiency in the future.

The common thread among these technologies is a shift in responsibilities. The GPU is taking on some specific tasks related to data access and processing that are currently handled by the CPU and traditional filesystem interactions. This shift leverages the GPU's strengths (parallel processing, high-bandwidth memory) and reduces the bottlenecks associated with the traditional CPU-centric data path. This is key to unlocking the full potential of PCIe 5.0 and fast NVMe SSDs.

comments.text: @Jayztwocents, I don't believe the jagged graph line on the GPU temperature is because of a low sample rate. I believe it is due to the precision of the temperature data. It looks like the value only changes in full degree Celsius increments. Not sure how the data was collected, but the data may be compressed in some fashion on the card or possibly on the collection software. The manufacturer may have decided that making cooling adjustments for anything less than a degree change was unnecessary, or possibly continuously changing the fan speed reduced the life of the fans. It also could be that the uncertainty of the temperature sensor they selected was high enough that temperature changes of less than a degree could be chalked up to instrument uncertainty.

Ok, seeing this I can say that I am kind of disappointed, as was looking to it as an upgrade for my 3080Ti:
1. In 4K it is doing better compared to competition, 5070Ti
2. It is definitely not on par with 5070Ti
3. RT is not as good as I was hoping for
Having USD1K budget, and 5080 being out of reach not worth all-an-all, I think the closest option as upgrade path for 3080Ti, as I see is (priority wise):
1. 4080 Super, if I manage to get it below USD850 (second hand)
2. 5070Ti, if manage to get it around MSRP
3. 9070 XT, if around MSRP, though not sure if this is now a good option 
Otherwise, price wise AMD got it close to right, very good and not being greedy, but $100 less will make it more compelling to new users.
Just wish they also had 9080 XT for $750 - performance on-par or beating 4080 Super. :)

comments.text:
I wish these reviews weren't all about framerates. 

Am I the only person who is more interested in a GPU that runs cooler at a framerate I like? 

Having a 3080ti I can play most games at 4k with pretty high settings (undervolted), but I often use DLSS simply to lower the temperature. 

I don't need super high framerates, I'm happy with 60-90fps and reasonably cool running system!

What I don't want is to have game in my underpants during summer with an aircon unit pointed at me! 

So a GPU can run this game at 200fps, but how many people have a monitor that actually take advantage of that? I have a 144hz monitor, but I rarely play games that get anywhere near that! 

Any chance that future reviews could reflect the temperatures that GPU's produce at framerates that I assume most people are happy with?

Oh and "in a case", not an open system, which I see you are using to measure temps.

comments.text:
AMD’s GPU department still seems to be in denial about the fact that more and more people aren’t buying GPUs just for gaming—especially not in the higher price range. Maybe we should just conclude that while AMD builds great processors, they shouldn’t release any GPU models without the ability to accelerate workloads beyond gaming.

This is where the green giant has been leading for a long time. It started with rendering and VFX processing through CUDA and OptiX, but what’s even more important and exciting now is AI acceleration—img2img, txt2img, txt2vid, you name it. Watching 24GB of ultra-fast VRAM sit there with GPU usage at 3% while waiting hours for AI calculations to finish—meanwhile, your neighbor’s five-year-old RTX card has already generated 20 images—is beyond frustrating.

AMD went the wrong way, dropping useful libraries like Mantle and Vulkan. Even advanced OpenGL libraries don’t run smoothly. I guess we’ll have to wait another 10 years—unless Intel steps up with a better solution to challenge the green giant.

comments.text:
For generation uplift, it's crap. The only good things are it is better in RT (If you use it) and that the price is more responsible. It is proving that the idea that the next gen mid card will be X percent better then the last gen flag ship is gone. The 7900XTX still proved out to be a better card and the 7900XT trades blows. So, generational, it's not a great uplift just like Nvidia, the difference is the price. From a buying new or going back multigen it looks like a very good card and much better then Nvidia in cost for the performance. It's basically like Nvidia for gen upgrade, if you are on higher end last gen, skip But if you are 2 or 3 gens back, it's a great uplift and if you are building new it's the best option unless you have money to burn. 

Before flaming, I have a 7900XTX in one of my pc's currently and I love the card. I am not shilling, I am being honest and treating AMD like Nvidia was treated. We can't say that a small uplift from last gen is a "do not buy" for Nvidia and then say the opposite for AMD because we like them more. It's a "do not buy" if you are on higher end last gen and a really good buy comparatively if you are on older or looking to build new. Of course this is all based on seeing cards at and around MSRP.

comments.text: @joee7452  The 7900XTX came out at $1000, the 9070XT is coming out at $600. In terms of price, it compares to the 7800XT, and it crushes that across the board. The gains in RT pushing it past the 7900XTX in most scenarios is just icing on the cake. The 7800XT competed with the 4070 on raster performance, but it struggled to compete with a 4060 in heavy RT scenarios. The 9070XT is consistently competing with the 5070ti on Raster and beats the 5070 in most RT scenarios. Coupled with what I saw on Digital Foundry with FSR4, this makes AMD a better or equal value for everything but AI training. This hasn't been the case since the RX 480 vs GTX1070 days, which is why people are happy. I am still running my old GTX 1070 and I originally wanted to upgrade to an RTX 3080, except those ended up never being available anywhere close to MSRP. Since then, I've been hoping AMD can be competitive again to force prices down. From a 1070, this 9070XT is the first card that has me excited (if I can find it near MSRP) since the RTX30 series.

comments.text:
Answer: The real generation gap or leap (or the jump) is PCIe5.0 in itself. 

PCIe 5.0 doubles the bandwidth of PCIe 4.0, which means significantly faster data transfer rates between components like GPUs, SSDs, and other peripherals.  If we assume a very efficient compression algorithm that achieves a 2:1 compression ratio (which is a reasonable estimate for some types of data), then PCIe 5.0's theoretical compressed bandwidth could be as high as 256 GB/s. Thus current, PCIe5.0 = 4GB/s each direction. PS5 custom I/O, 5.5 to 9 GB/s. PCIe 5.0 theoretical potential, 256 GB/s. AMD and Nvidia's line drop here, does not provide that compressed bandwidth potential. The fundamental shift is to PCIe 5.


PS5 has a custom I/O complex with dedicated hardware for decompression, allowing it to achieve those impressive compressed speeds. (and this is like 4-5 years old Technology now) Current GPUs from AMD and Nvidia don't fully exploit PCIe 5.0's capabilities, particularly in terms of compressed bandwidth. Once again, PS5's I/O up to 9-10 gb/s compressed, is old tech now, in 2025. (though still holds up)  Artificial intelligence could play a crucial role in optimizing I/O performance (this is more expected today).

Secondly and next, we need to benchmark in 8K as the standard, and next year's standard. It's a logical next step for benchmarking as displays and content that support 8K become more prevalent. Thus, And a true Data I/O benchmark and VRAM storage for "computational storage" and assets storage, is also the real and best complimentary benchmarks. Modern Apps and Games rely heavily on fast access to large datasets and efficient asset streaming. VRAM capacity and speed are becoming increasingly important as datasets grow larger and more complex. Developing standardized tests that specifically evaluate 8K performance, data I/O, and VRAM utilization is crucial for fair and consistent comparisons.

Lastly, Stability is still one of the top most important measurements for Robustness, AMD and Nvidia cannot abandon that, even though haven't, but if they have ... this is more important than inference time etc. While inference time (the time it takes for a model to process data and produce a result) is an important metric, especially in AI applications, it shouldn't come at the cost of stability. A slightly slower but stable system is often preferable to a faster but unreliable one. As GPUs become more complex and powerful, and as software pushes their limits further, maintaining stability becomes even more challenging. It's crucial that AMD and Nvidia continue to prioritize stability alongside performance advancements. But once again, and, to their credit, both AMD and Nvidia have generally maintained a strong focus on stability in their GPU designs. They invest significant resources in testing, validation, and driver development to ensure their products deliver reliable performance.

comments.text: while it might help, AMD and nvidia have both flip flopped so many times over the years that it can become a confusing mess.. e.g. pre 10 series nvidia had a 1:2 ratio of SM to cuda core while AMD it was 1:5 then nvidia switched to 1:5 and AMD switched to 1:2. it would take an hour just explaining the differences that the average buyer just doesn't have the attention span. all they see is number bigger, buy bigger number and you're never going to change that. hence why mobo AIB's put dual 8 pin eps on boards when a single 8pin EPS handles 588w, or nvidia puts a 600w 12vHP connector on a card that can run with an 8+6, the list goes on and on.. it's a marketing mind game that is designed to control consumer buying habits that has existed ever since humans started bartering between each other. end of the day you can only compare them within that specific generation/architecture.

comments.text:
The problem with the 50xx series is  legit ''it doesnt work'' 
Which was Nvidias whole gameplan and selling point. IT JUST WORKS. 
Thats the whole reason i ditched AMDs horrible loud Jet engine Cards (looking at you rx 60xx series) with even worse Drivers that just keep crashing watching a YouTube Video. 

Still. I would rather go for a 4070 then the new AMD GPU even if i lose perfomance. 
Only because....Nvidia didnt let me down with their past cards compared to AMD who had ALWAYS some kind of problem or bug or very bad performance hick ups.

But also we should consider. Nvidia gives 0 shits about the low/mid budget cards market. They make so much money with AI and stuff...They can afford to ditch that marked. 
And with their AI knowledge it makes sense that they try to ''elevate'' their Low/mid range cards in to a much higher price category by using their AI stuff. Which is on one hand great. DLSS is incredible and looks awesome and can be a reason why a GPU can be relevant even 5 years later. But its also expensive and just pushes these Cards way higher than they should be. Also they can literally LIE about the Performance because of AI upscaling shenanigans. 

TL:DR Not a fan of AMD GPUSs because of some anecdotal history but also NVidia is burning bridges and their apparently fine with it. Which sucks. 
If your happy with the new AMD Cards and they Work. Hey more power to you. Seriously. But if youre the kinda Guy who just wants a PC for Gaming and the moment Troubleshooting begins your annoyed and pissed of...just invest in a 4070 or something from Nvidia (not the 50xx series tho)

comments.text: (gamer) life changing advice related to 17m46 frametime graph Jayz shows thx to lossless scaling demos I discovered the recipe for super smooth gaming, it's not 200-400fps that look like the armor of a chaos spacemarine that gives you ultimate gaming but the lack of spike it's them you see the stutter the freezes the "this doesn't look like 100fps" lossless scaling best practice is limit fps to 60 with RTSS (which works better than ingame fps limit vsync) which if you setup your game for your gpu or have a powerful enough one will give you an ultra flat 1 pixel high frametimes graph (below 60 will feel laggy target 60 or more but still way under what your gpu can do it should not be stressed) then use lossless framegen x2 to reach your monitor Hz and activate vsync  (60fps-120Hz or 72fps-144Hz) I'm not exagerating I tought "I wasted 10 years playing my games all wrong" and I walk the walk I'm now playing most games 60fps x2 lossless rather than real 120fps  it's incredibly smoother like JayzTwoCents explains with the 9070XT smooth is king (if you don't want to use lossless still use RTSS and limit your fps to a number giving less or no spikes)
